author: @axe8071
text: Simple Portscanner:  import socket ip = input("Enter IP to scan: ") s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)  def porttry(ip, port):     try:         s.connect((ip, port))         return True     except:         return None  for port in range(0, 100000):     value = porttry(ip, port)     if value == None:         print("Port not open on %d " % port)     else:         print("Port opened on %d " % port)         break     ip

author: @wdavid3116
text: If you're doing socket communications you almost definitely should not be using pickle. pickle is insecure and can be used by an attacker to gain arbitrary code execution on a server. It should never be used when the source of the data is not known, for example on a server that can be connected to by people other than you. It can be used under certain circumstances, but if you only know one way to serialise data in python it shouldn't be pickle. Pickle is very powerful and convenient but that convenience comes with a price WRT security which is laid out in the documentation. JSON (if you don't do something stupid like use eval to parse it,) Protobufs, flatbuffers and the struct module are all better options. https://docs.python.org/3/library/pickle.html
